thread.title: Honda agrees to repay $24 million to minority auto-loan borrowers
thread.title_full: Honda agrees to repay $24 million to minority auto-loan borrowers - MarketWatch

author: By     Daniel Goldstein
title: Honda agrees to repay $24 million to minority auto-loan borrowers
text:
Daniel Acker/Bloomberg Honda Motor Co.’s auto finance unit will pay out $24 million in compensation to minority borrowers after the federal government said the car maker charged African-American, Hispanic and Asian borrowers higher interest rates on car loans than it did for whites — even if their credit was good.
The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said Honda’s HMC, +1.10% past practices resulted in thousands of African-American, Hispanic, and Asian and Pacific Islander borrowers paying higher interest rates than white borrowers for their auto loans, without regard to their creditworthiness.
Honda’s pricing and compensation structure meant thousands of minority borrowers from January 2011 through July of this year paid, on average, from $150 to over $250 more for their auto loans, the CFPB alleged .
The McLean, Va. based National Automobile Dealers Association (NADA) said that the CFPB order would hurt the ability of individual consumers and dealers to negotiate and offer lower rates to the most qualified borrowers for fear of further CFPB sanctions.
While individually over the life of the loan the amounts are not a lot, to the borrower and the lender, the several hundred dollars they received added significantly to the profits the dealerships received on individual car sales and sales commissions. The CFPB said that Honda would set up a toll-free hotline for consumers to submit loan details to see if they qualified for a refund.
“The CFPB is committed to creating a fair marketplace for all consumers, and other auto lenders should take note of today’s action,” said CFPB director Richard Cordray. “Honda’s proactive decision to move to a new pricing and compensation system demonstrates industry leadership and represents a significant step toward protecting consumers from discrimination.”
Auto loans are the third-largest source of outstanding household debt in the U.S., after mortgages and student loans, the CFPB said.
In In an investigation that began in April 2013, Honda’s auto lender set a risk-based interest rate, or “buy rate,” that it conveyed to auto dealers, the CFPB said. Honda then allowed auto dealers to charge a higher interest rate when they finalized the deal with the customer, the consumer agency said. The “dealer markup” gave auto sellers them the discretion to charge consumers different rates regardless of consumer creditworthiness, the CFPB alleged. The agency said that Honda permitted dealers to markup consumers’ interest rates as much as 2.25% for contracts with terms of 5 years or less, and 2% for contracts with longer terms.
American Honda Finance Corporation said it will put new measures in place to address discretionary auto loan pricing and compensation practices, according to the federal agency. Honda will reduce dealer discretion to markup the interest rate to only 1.25% above the buy rate for auto loans with terms of 5 years or less, and 1% for auto loans with longer terms, according to the CFPB.
In December 2013, the CFPB and the Justice Department ordered Ally Financial Inc. and Ally Bank to pay $80 million in consumer restitution and an $18 million civil penalty for similar discrimination against 235,000 minority auto loan borrowers in a similar scheme.
